The maximum delay D can be identified as the maximum observable delay in the data, which may change as the time series extends, or can be fixed at some value D thought to represent a very long delay. In the latter case, θ
D can be modeled as the probability of delay ≥ D. For dengue, we choose to fix D at 10 weeks, since over 99% of the cases observed in the first two years (prior to producing out-of-sample nowcasts) were reported within 10 weeks. For influenza, we chose D to be the longest possible delay within the 27-week moving window, or D = 26. The implications of choosing a maximum delay D within a moving window of W weeks means that the nowcast will include all cases arising with delays greater than or equal to D but less than or equal to W, thus excluding all cases with delays greater than W (see the reporting triangle in S6 Table).
